title: jsConnect Plugin: Takeover of existing account

profile.name: Vanilla
profile.about: Vanilla is a powerfully simple discussion forum you can easily customize to make as unique as your community.

vulnerability_information:
Description
-----------

The current version (1.5.5) of the official jsConnect plugin allows the takeover of an existing account that wasn't created using SSO - eg a previously existing admin user - by registering an account with the same name using SSO.

A successfull attack requires one request to be issued by an authenticated administrator. This can for example take place via CSRF. Other than this, the attacker does not need any special permissions.

POC
---

1. Prerequisit: Enable jsConnect and add an SSO service (eg a local WordPress instance using the Vanilla WordPress plugin). Add a user - eg `admin` - in Vanilla, eg using `vanilla-core-2-6/dashboard/user` -> "Add User" (or use the admin user which was created on installation). 
2. Attacker: Register a user with the same name and an arbitrary password in the SSO service (eg WordPress).
3. Attacker: Register with Vanilla using SSO, using the credentials from step 2. After authenticating with the SSO service, Vanilla will say that the username is already taken. Clicking on "Connect" will issue a POST request. The response will inform the attacker that a password is required. 
4. Attacker: Create a CSRF payload for the previous POST request and send it to an authenticated administrator.
5. Victim Admin: Execute the CSRF payload.
6. Attacker: Sign in using SSO. Use the credentials for the account of the SSO service created in step 2. The attacker will now have access to the account that was created in step 1, without having had access to the password for that account. 

Example CSRF code:

    <html>
      <body>
        <form action="http://192.168.0.102/vanilla-core-2-6/entry/connect/jsconnect?client_id=test" method="POST">
          <input type="hidden" name="TransientKey" value="" />
          <input type="hidden" name="hpt" value="" />
          <input type="hidden" name="Target" value="http://192.168.0.102/vanilla-core-2-6/discussions" />
          <input type="hidden" name="JsConnect" value="email=admin2%40example.com&name=admin2&photourl=http%3A%2F%2F1.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2F7ab1e57078d6ad175c76f0c560b7688a%3Fs%3D96%26d%3Dmm%26r%3Dg&roles=subscriber&uniqueid=9&wp_nonce=d79ea1a8aa&client_id=test&signature=e22bcb0cb9042e6dfe2640a48afcc62c" />
          <input type="hidden" name="UserSelect" value="17" />
          <input type="hidden" name="ConnectName" value="" />
          <input type="hidden" name="ConnectPassword" value="" />
          <input type="hidden" name="Connect" value="Connect" />
          <input type="submit" value="Submit request" />
        </form>
      </body>
    </html>

The values would of course need to be adapted, but are all known to the attacking user.

I haven't looked into it in-depth yet, but my assumption is that the vulnerable code is actually in Vanilla core, likely in `applications/dashboard/controllers/class.entrycontroller.php:connect()`, so other functionality outside of the jsConnect plugin may be affected as well.

## Impact

Takeover of Vanilla account.

activities.message:
I just noticed that step 5. does not need to be done by an administrator, but any registered user; the permissions of that user do not matter.

This increases the severity significantly, as no user interaction is required.

An attacker can take over the admin account - or any other account - as long as the attacker can register an account with the same name with the SSO service. 

They can then use any arbitrary account they registered previously to perform step 5. and thus associate that account with the admin account.

I @dexterr,

sure, see attachment. Some info on the config and what is happening in the POC:

Relevant Configuration
----------------------

Vanilla jsConnect: 
Auto Connect: Off (the issue is not related to this setting)
This is trusted connection and can sync roles & permissions: Off (the issue is not related to this setting)

Vanilla Users
--------------

realuser: regular member, controlled by attacker (not registered with SSO)
aaa: administrator, to be taken over (not registered with SSO)

Wordpress Users (SSO provider)
---------------

aaa: Registered by attacker (subscriber, but the role doesn't matter)

Video Poc
---------

In the first window (Firefox regular mode), the POC shows the sign-in using SSO. Connecting the Wordpress aaa user to Vanilla doesn't work as the username is already taken and the attacker doesn't know the password that is used in Vanilla.

The second window (Firefox private mode) is used to get a valid session cookie for Vanilla. The user realuser is a regular member, not an administrator.

Finally, the Burp window shows a repeat of the request from the failed attempt in the first window with the cookie from realuser. Submitting this does two things:

- It logs user realuser into the aaa admin account (via the returned session cookie)
- It links the aaa Wordpress user (known to the attacker) to the aaa Vanilla user (not known to the attacker). 

The parts of the POC from 0:51 to 1:13 are not really relevant, you can ignore them. I wanted to show point 1., but then decided that point 2. will be easier and clearer to show in a video.

If you have further questions, just let me know.

summaries.content:
Version 1.5.5 of the Vanilla Forum single sign-on plugin "jsConnect" allows the takeover of any existing Vanilla Forum account that wasn't created using SSO - eg a previously existing admin user. 

The attack can be performed by registering an account with the name of the account that is to be taken over with the SSO provider and linking the accounts via a specifically crafted request issued by a third account. 

Initially it was assumed that this third account needs administrator permissions and an attack is thus only possible with user interaction via CSRF. This assumption turned out to be false. Any registered account can be used, meaning the account takeover requires no user interaction.
